Message.Title: There is a thin line
Message.Msg: I am long AAPL, but at the same time, there is a thing line as to what constitutes copying technology. Technology is always being copied and improved and that is the key word "improved". If you look at human history, everything is copied. Your computer, your car, your radio, your tv and yes even your phone and especially your smartphone. AAPL was not the first one in the smart phone business and it must have copied but improved on its technology. But just because you improve on something that does not give you the absolute right to all future improvements in that specific field and in this case the smart phone business. Re,member Samsung manufactures almost every component of its smart phone with the exception of the cpu unit running it. AAPL on the other hand is the world's best marketer of its products. If Bell held rights to all future improvements we would still be using just landlines. I think we hit 624 today? I SURE HOPE SO!

Topic.Title: Talk of split is NOT just rumors. It is seriously being considered, IMHO.

Message.Msg: I have followed this story through many articles, but they all come back to one source: Tony Sacconaghi of Bernstein in a recent research note to clients. He makes the case for the split because it would help get AAPL into the Dow if they wanted to, which is certainly true. That is, there's no way AAPL could get into the Dow at the current price. But nowhere in his research note is there any indication of a source, anonymous or otherwise, that suggests this is actually in progress. In other words, the research note is one of speculation based upon what Mr Sacconaghi believes would be a great idea. Not that I would argue with that, but I want to point out two things: (1) the various headlines attached to this story assert without any proof that Apple is strongly considering this, and (2) betting on Apple to do a specific thing on only the concept that it would be a great idea may or may not be a safe bet. Of course, the venerable New York Times (tongue firmly planted in cheek) picked up on this concept and ran a story on it as if they had uncovered Watergate. In conclusion, I don't see any information out there to support this other than Sacconaghi opinion. Not that I disagree with it, but I think we need to put the media into perspective. Thompson

Message.Title: Split is coming
Message.Msg: There's always a rumor going around about Apple (AAPL). For tech geeks. the chatter is usually about when the next iPhone or iPad is coming out and what new features those products will have? But for Wall Street traders, the speculation is often about whether Apple may finally split its stock ... and make itself a more likely candidate to be included in the exclusive club of 30 known as the Dow Jones Industrial Average. An analyst from Bernstein reignited the chatter with a report Tuesday suggesting Apple could split and then be invited to pass the Dow's velvet rope. But I've argued for years that Apple belongs in the Dow. It's the world's most valuable company. And it is arguably more relevant than any of the other techs already in the Dow: be it strong companies like IBM (IBM), Microsoft (MSFT) and Intel (INTC) or struggling Cisco Systems (CSCO) and woeful Hewlett-Packard (HPQ). Dropping HP in favor of Apple could make sense -- except for the fact that the Dow is a price-weighted average and not a market cap-weighted index like the S&P 500 or the Nasdaq Composite. Apple already has a big influence on the daily direction of the Nasdaq and S&P 500 because of its gargantuan market value of nearly $575 billion. But Apple would really skew the Dow if it were added with a stock price north of $600. Hence, calls for a stock split. If Apple were to say, split its shares 6-1, that would knock the price down to a little higher than $100. That would still make Apple one of the more expensive stocks in the Dow on a per share basis. But it could be tolerable to the people in charge of running the Dow. McDonald's (MCD), Caterpillar (CAT), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Coca-Cola (KO) and 3M (MMM) trade for more than $80 a share. Chevron's (CVX) stock price is above $100. And IBM trades for nearly $200.

Message.Title: AAPL is in an up trend for sure!
Message.Msg: Make no mistake about it. Today's action and volume are week because the resistance from $611-$617 is very strong. 70% of today's trades are automated. If the MMs hit the trip wires too hard at the resistance levels down she goes fast. If you recall the end of last year until the beginning of April, AAPLs rise was slow and steady on low volumes. No doubt about it. $650 and $700 are way too ambitious. I also believe after Sept. 12th is when we will see the big down draft in AAPL. The MMs will no doubt want to make their gains before the new product launch and will exit after making a healthy gain so they have no exposure for what might be a poor Q4 quarter.

I am big fans of both Apple and Tiger and enjoy watching both succeed.

Topic.Title: Why down? Divy is in about a week

Message.Msg: Along with the other reasons mentioned in this thread, the single biggest influence has to do with weekly options expiration. The institutional guys don't change their positions in the stock. They move shares back and forth all day long and end the day with the same number of shares they started with. They make money on the spread and they make huge amounts of money writing options contracts. They then move the stock up and down while destroying the value of the contracts they sold. Meanwhile, 98% of the "traders" posting on this message board dream of "hitting the big one"! Making us all suckers for the next round of "up and down" stock pricing.

Topic.Title: AAPL has significantly broken through (PM) the long running bear trend line

Message.Msg: I didn`t find the info anywhere. It`s my own charting analysis. It`s simple, really, and all based on trend lines and price action in different time frames--and on often experienced or usual price action that occurs under particular circumstances. Trends in different time frames. Support and resistance areas. Price action behavior at these points. Extremeness of moves. Unsustainable and sustainable behavior. Buying/Selling pressure. Volume Spikes, climaxes, reversals, breakouts, continuations, failed breakouts, trend channels (width, envelopes), trading ranges (tight, wide, ascending, descending, flat) moving averages...typical behavior, testing points (repeatedly) rejection or success (of buyers or sellers) at these critical points. This descending bear channel line is drawn from the April 10 open through the 7/11 high (the highest high since then) and extend on as long as you wish. This line becomes a significant line of resistance. You can see how the price action behaves when it is tested. On 7/11, after a 6-7 day parabolic spike up, it was rejected (at 619.87). This resulted in a three day pullback of 29 points from extreme to extreme. This high also coincided with the last two highs (that formed a double top) 4/19 at 620.25 (the first lower high after a precipitous drop from all time high) and 4/26 at 618.22 (after earnings spike). It is no coincidence that on the 7/11 it was rejected at 619.87. These points become significant. Since Tuesday 7/11 (again, the highest high since 10 April), the bear trend line has been tested three more times on the daily chart: on 7/20 at 617.12--rejected, resulting in a three day pullback culminating in a climatic bear spike (after earnings)--a total move of just over 50 points. This was also unsustainable behavior. Yesterday at 611.70 (intra day the line was tested repeatedly on the 5 min chart and rejected. But it managed to hover around it though the close. And today (it actually broke through pre-market) and has tried several times to break through again, but so far it is failing. So what now? you might ask. A pullback over the next few days would be no shock. At the same time there are a lot of rumors and buying pressure, but that might be fizzling and not enough. I said earlier what might happen if the break out is successful or fails. More specifically on the failure: you could reasonable expect a three day pullback (including today) down to about 595 (600 if the buying momentum stays strong for the In-div date a week from today). A harsher and stronger pull-back could bring it into the 570s over the next 2 or three weeks before finally having a successful break out with follow through of that hampering bear trend line closer to Sept 12 when the line would be down around 600. At this point it`s looking bearish, especially with the extremity of the run up over the last 5 days. But with AAPL you never know. We might just get a one day breather and another unsustainable bull spike up. Until 617 and 619 have been firmly breached and closes hold over the bear trend line (now at 610.90), we are not quite on firm soil. But hey, fundamentally things are daisies. GL

Topic.Title: Apple may go down to 577 (Buy all you can) one more time before 700

Message.Msg: we want buy at 570 but China Time screw we up Apple to postpone iPhone 5 amid undersupply of 28nm chips Business Companies Apple to postpone iPhone 5 amid undersupply of 28nm chips Staff Reporter The iPhone 4S on display at a store in Sichuan. (Photo/Xinhua) The iPhone 4S on display at a store in Sichuan. (Photo/Xinhua) Apple is set to postpone the debut of its iPhone 5 because high-end chips used in the device are in short supply, reports the Shanghai-based First Financial Daily. The newest generation of the iPhone uses chips manufactured using 28-nanometer fabrication, an advanced production technology known only to a few companies, said Gu Wenjun, an analyst with market research firm iSuppli. Apple's leading chip supplier, Qualcomm, will be able to tackle the 28nm chip undersupply only by the end of this year, said Qi Fei, a spokesman for Qualcomm China. The problem arose during the second quarter of this year, as demand for 28nm chips has been growing alongside the popularity of smartphones. As part of its efforts to resolve the undersupply problem, Qualcomm entered partnerships with South Korea's Samsung and Taiwan-based United Microelectronics to manufacture chips, said the daily. As Apple keeps firm control over its inventory, it is cautious about selecting new suppliers. Its heavy demand for components often drive suppliers to operate at full capacity. Partners must meet Apple's tough demands or risk losing a major buyer; its production chain consists of 156 companies. This means any single supplier that fails to pull its weight can undermine the entire production chain, said the daily. The shortage of high-end chips could affect the supply of smartphones produced by Chinese brands Xiaomi and 360, as they also rely on Qualcomm for 28nm chips. The postponement of the iPhone 5 launch will give Apple's lead rivals — HTC and Samsung — a much-needed reprieve, as their phones won't have to compete with the iPhone 5 head-on.

Message.Title: Apple Reports Third Quarter Results
Message.Msg: Apple Reports Third Quarter Results 17 Million iPads Sold Board Declares Quarterly Dividend of $2.65 per Common Share CUPERTINO, California—July 24, 2012—Apple® today announced financial results for its fiscal 2012 third quarter ended June 30, 2012. The Company posted quarterly revenue of $35.0 billion and quarterly net profit of $8.8 billion, or $9.32 per diluted share. These results compare to revenue of $28.6 billion and net profit of $7.3 billion, or $7.79 per diluted share, in the year-ago quarter. Gross margin was 42.8 percent compared to 41.7 percent in the year-ago quarter. International sales accounted for 62 percent of the quarter’s revenue. The Company sold 26.0 million iPhones in the quarter, representing 28 percent unit growth over the year-ago quarter. Apple sold 17.0 million iPads during the quarter, an 84 percent unit increase over the year-ago quarter. The Company sold 4.0 million Macs during the quarter, a two percent unit increase over the year-ago quarter. Apple sold 6.8 million iPods, a 10 percent unit decline from the year-ago quarter. Apple’s Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $2.65 per share of the Company’s common stock. The dividend is payable on August 16, 2012, to stockholders of record as of the close of business on August 13, 2012. “We’re thrilled with record sales of 17 million iPads in the June quarter,” said Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO. “We’ve also just updated the entire MacBook line, will release Mountain Lion tomorrow and will be launching iOS 6 this Fall. We are also really looking forward to the amazing new products we’ve got in the pipeline.” “We’re continuing to invest in the growth of our business and are pleased to be declaring a dividend of $2.65 per share today,” said Peter Oppenheimer, Apple’s CFO. “Looking ahead to the fourth fiscal quarter, we expect revenue of about $34 billion and diluted earnings per share of about $7.65.” Apple will provide live streaming of its Q3 2012 financial results conference call beginning at 2:00 p.m. PDT on July 24, 2012 at
